review:
[b]6/10[/b]

Get all the snake puppers to their food bowls.

[b]What is it:[/b] A snake-inspired puzzle game. In each level there are between one and 4 puppies that can grow and shrink, and the goal is to get each puppy to a bowl of the same color as the puppy, optionally eating all of the hams spread on the floor. The posterior of the puppy doesn't move, only the head does, growing or shrinking the body to cover all the tiles the head has been on. Other mechanisms used are aforementioned hams that must be collected, but these are optional and influence how many stars are awarded for each level, "wormholes" that go underground and teleport the head from one tile to another, and conveyor belts that automatically move the puppy along in one direction.

I liked a decent part of the levels, though not all, since the mechanics are interesting and can make up some clever puzzles. However, this is an outdated mobile game with very few QoL features that would make it suitable for a PC or the Steam Deck. Some of the raster graphics are low-res and look pixelated/blurry when mixed with the vector ones, the animations often end up in a loop or are mistimed, it works best with a mouse/finger and barely with a keyboard, and almost no settings.

[b]How hard is it:[/b] Easy to moderate. Only one level gave me some trouble, since it was more like a maze you could get lost into than a thinky puzzle requiring logic. Most of the levels are on the easy side, one in every 5 levels is harder and has an achievement associated with it. No level skipping, but multiple levels are open at a time.

[b]How long is it:[/b] 80 levels for about 2-3 hours of playtime.

[b]Level design:[/b] Decent overall, but not impressive, many I felt were pedestrian.

[b]Quality:[/b] Average. Decent puzzles. Mixed experience depending on what you're playing with, from not-working on a keyboard, decent with a finger, almost there with a controller. Undo only works on a controller, but it's a weird kind of undo where you're just shrinking the currently selected dog, not a true global undo, so the same can be achieved by simply shrinking it manually. The keyboard controls are not explained, not rebindable, and make no sense on a keyboard since they use ABXY like on a controller. Almost no settings, decent achievements, no cloud saving, buggy animations.

[b]Worth the price:[/b] Wait for a big discount.

[b]Most positive aspect for me:[/b] The conveyor belts make up good puzzles where you have to keep on growing and shrinking to make stops along the belt.

[b]Most negative aspect for me:[/b] The maze levels where you have to find out the right sequence of wormholes.

review:
I don't hate dogs, I promise.

This might seem like a Numberlink variant, but it actually plays very differently. You're not going to be drawing concentric lines like you do in most Numberlink games which honestly makes it feel less satisfying. Waterslides are weird, the way you're able/required to use temporary lines/puppers to block slides and alter the paths of other lines feels weird and I don't like it. Especially without an undo button, since sometimes you have to make use of many temp lines that build on each other, and making a mistake means you have to start the chain over. 

It's a cute game, but I didn't really enjoy most of the levels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11208, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1576070086}
review:
Puzzle Puppers is a simple to learn but challenging "line drawing" puzzle game where the "lines" are elongated multicolour dogs.   Stretch each dog over the chicken legs to their matching colour food bowls to complete each level.   As the difficulty increases there's typically only one solution to each puzzle so it's just a matter of working it out. 

This really feels like a mobile/tablet/browser game.  The developers here are gouging by dumping it onto Steam with a whopping $7 price tag for something that could have been done in Flash.   Games like this can be played for free in browser/mobile platforms so I can't recommend anyone pays for it here.

Not a bad little puzzle game. Let's get into the pros and cons. 

Pros
+ Good presentation. The graphics are colourful and nice. It has cute dogs. What's not to love?
+ It's fairly cheap. 

Neutral
= The game is fairly easy. If you're a die hard puzzle fan looking for the next brain teaser then this is probably not it. However if you're looking for a relaxing puzzle game then this might be it. 
= The game is fairly short. If you want a puzzle game that will last you hundred of hours, then this is not it. I completed this game in 2.5 hours.

Cons.
- There's a graphical bug that exists as of writing this review, where the dogs will start moving very... strangely. When they're standing still they will seperate into two pieces for example. Not a very pleasant image for such a cute game.  
- Level 80 is pretty annoying. The level is just a bunch of holes with no way to tell which hole leads where so you sorta just end up randomly moving around trying to figure out which hole leads where with trial and error. If there was a way to tell which hole leads where without checking this wouldn't be a problem, but as it stands there is no way to know without manually checking. There is however guides here on steam for each puzzle so if you don't feel like dealing with the semi randomness you can just using a guide. 

Conclusion.
Overall it's a short, cute, relaxing puzzle game. The price is just right and in the end it's a game I would recommend. If you're looking to be entertained and relaxed for a few hours.

review:
Well, let me tell you I really loved this cute indie game!
And by the way, once in a while even the Steam store accepts the right tags - this game is rightly flagged as indie, puzzle and casual but no way "for kids only" or something like that.
In fact, it's a very nice and somehow challenging puzzle game that can be definitely enjoyed by the whole family, of course if the player likes indie puzzle games. Or cute puppies. For its price, it's definitely worth it in my opinion.
The game is made in Unity and unfortunately it really lacks of display configuration modes (you can basically play only on "high" graphic quality and a single resolution if you want to go windowed), but it's ok since it's quite light to be downloaded and played.
On one hand, the game features more than 80 levels and so it has a nice rate of replayability - plus, it also offers lots of language customization options in the in-game menu so that everyone can play it even if he doesn't know English.
On the other hand, the 80+ levels have all three hearts/stars.. meaning that if you want to complete them all, you'll probably need to go through multiple playthroughs - although all the levels aren't that big, meaning that you can play this game whenever you want and even for just 10 minutes!
Unfortunately, the game has a big downside - it has no tutorial at all, and you're somehow forced to search for information here on these pages.. since it's not that easy, really. I mean, it - is - easy.. but just if you're accustomed to these games or to the good old '90s trial-and-error procedure.
Something that many young kids born with smartphones and internet don't know that much xD
Anyways, you'll discover that you won't be able to remap your keys and your mouse will be useless in the game itself - you'll have the directional keys to move your puppies making them reach their bowls and their meat! Oh, well, the mouse can also be used to switch between the dogs you want to control, although the R keys makes the same work and it's way easier to use without touching your mouse at all.
Although being drawn in a funny and colorful way, the way in which the dogs stretch is really nice and the game gets within some levels a nice challenging factor. 
What should you do? Well, the game itself goes like a normal puzzle in which looong doggos will be your main source of fun. They will need both food and bowls, but new elements and obstacles will be added once in a few levels - first, you'll have to deal with more than one dog, meaning that you won't be able to cross their paths.. and fortunately, there are no timers anywhere so that you'll only have to deal with your number of moves if you care about the 1-3 stars you'll get after completing a level.
And it's also awesome that you can always retrace and undo back every single move of each dog, meaning that no restars are ever needed.
Then, you'll have to face obstacles: holes in the ground that will function as portals, forced directional keys on the ground (which are actually rivers).. well, the game really gets challenging even in the first level page!
I'd really recommend this game to anyone that loves puzzle games - it's for all the family, it's casual, it's challenging but it's also cute and relaxing (just look at the swinging dogs' tails when they get to eat!), there's no timer and no deaths are involved, you'll be able to undo every single move and get all the food needed for your hearts/stars, or just to direct every dog to its colored bowl.
Definitely a nice, refreshing indie puzzle game!

review:
Short but solid connect the lines game. 
It never gets hugely challenging even while getting all the collectibles (with one exception.), but its got some fairly clever levels, holes your pups can travel through, and some conveyor belt mechanics that can complicate things.

There are a couple of issues though:
Handling the pups can be a little dodgy at times, youll sometimes have to wrestle them round certain routes when conveyorbelts can easily snap them back from the slightest misclick. Holes also have an annoying tendency to fail back so you have to redrag the pup through it. By and large though its easy enough to churn through the levels.

Also, the last level felt like a gigantic leap in difficulty, so watch out for that. I believe I spent more time on it than entire pages of previous levels. (I actually thought it might have needed to be brute forced, but thankfully spotted ways in which the paths can be narrowed down a little more rapidly.)

I would probably wait for a sale given the short length and few handling issues, but otherwise its a neat little puzzler.

review:
Puzzle Puppers is a cute puzzle game. 
The aim is to lead a head of a streching dog to the bowl corresponding with its color while the dog's bottom stays in place. It looks very funny when a little doggie becomes a dog-snake.

The graphics is actually cute, the models are nice and colors are vivid. Soundtrack is cool and relaxing.

There are 80 levels in total. Most of them are fairy easy, only few were challenging for me, but I must admit, all of them are very enjoyable.

Animations of dogs sometimes get glitchy and it looks like they were cut in half. It looks very creepy, but at the same time it is absolutely hilarious.

The game offers no instruction at all. It was easy to figure out the point of the game, but it was not so easy to figure out controls - I preferred to use keyboard instead of mouse - R was to change a dog, B was to move the dog back.
Also launching the game for the first time leads you right into the first level ommiting the menu.
There is no exit button...

Nevertheless those issues are not serious enough to spoil the gameplay.
Puzzle Puppers is a very enjoyable game that I fully recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118980661', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1517371430}
review:
Is it a cute game with puppers? Yes. Is it a good puzzle game? Eh...

While the puzzles do work, and some of the mechanics feel unique, the game makes it very clear that it is a port of a mobile game: 3 star scoring system for levels, clearly optimized for touch screen controls, no "Quit" button on the home screen, etc. That's not fundamentally a bad thing, in this case it leaves the game with a general sense of unpolish. My biggest gripe is that every 4 levels you're returned to the level selection screen, even if you've unlocked the fifth level by getting all 3 stars on the previous ones. This means every 4 levels you have to scroll back through the pages of levels to go to the next as it always puts you pointed to the first level. The music is on the edge of being annoying where I'll leave it on for a while, then mute it.

I'll leave this review as positive as the tunnel and water stream mechanics make for unique puzzles. In many cases you have to form and re-form the lines to complete the levels, which I haven't encountered in similar puzzle games. However a lot of the appeal of the game is that it has dogs. Few of the levels really felt challenging, and throughout the 80 levels, I never really got a feeling of satisfaction upon completing a level, due largely to the things outlined above. It is a passable puzzle game, but if you're looking mainly for a puzzle game rather than a game with dogs, give this one a pass.

review:
It ended up having more variants in the puzzles than I thought, which is great.  It really is a fun, colourful, well thought out puzzle game. Some levels I had to think and move pups a lot to get the solution, others are very easy.  There is no tutorial or words but the levels are clear enough for you to work out what to do.  

Achievement hunters - all achievements are to get 3 hearts on each level.  Just pick up every ham bone in level to get 3 hearts, then get your pup to eat out of his colour co-ordinated bowl to finish level.  There are no timers (thankfully) and one dog can get all bones, not every dog has to get a bone.  

 There are 80 levels it has a level map.  Although there is no undo button if you click on your dog you can undo your moves.  There is a mute button for sounds and music but no slider.
On some levels you have to make multiple small temporary moves from another pup to get the original pup into the right position, those were my favourite levels.

I wish there were a lot more levels but just because I loved the fun game, and I hope they make many more puzzle puppers sequels.

edit - cards were added after I finished, which took ages to drop, I think my true playing time in total was nearer to 3.5 hrs.

N.B  It is currently available for free at app store so it's overpriced.  I'm not sure if this is a mobile port or they were released here and app at same time.
